bibl.title: Letter from J.F. Siler to Philip Showalter Hench, October 15, 1952

div1.p: Siler regrets the difficulty Hench has had with the Cubans and hopes Finlay doesn't receive all the credit. He solicits Hench's opinion in regards to increasing Blossom Reed's pension.

div1.head: Letter from J.F. Siler to Philip Showalter Hench, October 15, 1952
div1.opener:
GORGAS MEMORIAL INSTITUTE
OF
TROPICAL AND PREVENTIVE MEDICINE
INCORPORATED
-----
GORGAS MEMORIAL LABORATORY
EXECUTIVE OFFICES
1835 EYE STREET, NORTHWEST
WASHINGTON 6, D. C.
October 15, 1952
JOSEPH F. SILER
PRESIDENT
MAURICE H. THATCHER
VICE PRESIDENT AND GENERAL COUNSEL
WALTER A. BLOEDORN
SECRETARY
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minn
My dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
Thank you so much for your letter of October 8th advising me that the
date for the dedication of Camp Lazear had been postponed to December 3rd.
I had just seen Dr. Soper who had attended the International Congresses in
Havana and had assumed from my conversation with him that the date of the
dedication had been postponed and I am delighted to learn just when it is
to be held.

I regret so much the difficulty you are having with the people in
Cuba to use facts in connection with the dedication and I do hope that they
will not persist in gicing Dr. Finlay all the credit for everything.

I am so sorry that it will not be possible for you to attend the an-
nual meeting of the Walter Reed Memorial Association this year. I had at
first thought it might be desirable to eliminate the meeting for this
year because of the fact that you could not attend and that there was no
particular business to be brought up. However, in talking with General
Love, I learned he had just received our annual report of income from the
bank and he advises me that the income for the past year has been $1400.
In view of the fact that Blossom Reed's income has been materially reduced
since her mother's death and she gets only $84 to $85 a month at the present
time, we feel that it will be desirable to increase her income to $100 a
month. We will take this matter up at the annual meeting but I would appre-
ciate it very much if you would let me know if you concur in this increased
monthly payment to Blossom.

I hope that the Surgeon General will be able to go down for the dedi-
cation on December 9th and if not that he will certainly send General Streit.
As you undoubtedly know, it will be impossible for Gen. and Mrs. Reed to
attend because of General Reed's health and Blossom has advised us that it
will not be possible for her to go either.

closer.signed:
J. F. Siler
Col., (MC), USA, Rtd.
